thread.title: The Keary setback worse than Rusty
thread.title_full: The Keary setback worse than Rusty

title: The Keary setback worse than Rusty
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS IT’S been a whirlwind 12 months for Luke Keary. 
His falling out with South Sydney owner Russell Crowe last season and subsequent departure from the Rabbitohs to join archrivals the Sydney Roosters was well-publicised. 
But his wild NRL ride stretches back much further than that, well before carving up his old Bunnies outfit in a 20-6 defeat on Thursday night . 
After appearing in a handful of NRL games in 2013, Keary was set to be the Rabbitohs’ first choice five-eighth the following season until a pectoral muscle tear in the Auckland Nines sidelined him. 
The young playmaker was crushed, and that’s when mentor and former NRL star Matthew Johns reached out to him. Roosters win it in the wet 1:42 
Ben Ikin, Nathan Ryan and Ben Glover examine Jason Taylor’s sacking at the Wests Tigers and how it impacts the club and its roster going forward. 
You can also subscribe via iTunes or for Android users, listen on the iPP Podcast Player app. 
“When Michael Maguire first got the job at Souths, he brought him over to my place a few times, he was playing (under) 20s at that stage,” Johns told Thursday Night League in the lead up to Keary’s first game against Souths. 
“He’s just a great bloke. Old-fashioned sort of kid. 
“He tore his pec in the Nines and I remember I rung him and I said come over to the house. 
“He was really down in the dumps and he felt his career was in the balance — he hadn’t quite cracked it in first grade at that point. 
“I said we’ll go down to the park, walk around, have a bit of a talk. 
“I remember walking along just chatting away, and I looked, he wasn’t alongside me, he was about 10 yards behind. 
“I turned around and he had his head down, he had his arm in his sling and he said ‘Matty, I just want to tell you something. I’m scared I’m not going to make it’. 
“When someone says that to you, you know they’ll do anything. That hunger and desire he’s got, that fire in the belly is rare.” Luke Keary of the Roosters in action against the Rabbitohs on Thursday night. Source: Getty Images 
As history shows, Keary fought his way back into the Rabbitohs’ top 17 that year, became the team’s starting No. 6 and helped them to their drought-breaking premiership win. 
He was the star attention when he faced many of his old teammates and he didn’t disappoint, setting up two tries in the Roosters’ fourth straight win since he arrived at the club. 
“For a five foot nine fella, he’s taken on the line with conviction every time. He’s willing to cop the bumps,” Fox Sports ’ NRL expert Michael Ennis said. 
It’s true there have been a few bumps in Keary’s football journey, but he’s proven he can overcome adversity, even the odd Gladiator.
